caphereus: A promontory on the southeastern coast of Euboea, where the rocky coast was dangerous for ships
hecuba: Queen of Troy, wife of Priam and mother of, among others
ionian sea: The sea that lies between the Balkan peninsula and Italy, today usually called the Adriatic
laomedon: King of Troy and, in Euripides’ genealogy, father of Ganymede, Tithonus, and Priam
menelaus: King of Sparta, brother of Agamemnon, and husband of Helen
olympus: Mountain in northeastern Thessaly; home of the Olympian gods
peneus: River in Thessaly that flows to the sea between Olympus and Ossa. phthia: Region of Thessaly over which Peleus and his descendants ruled
priam: King of Troy, son of Laomedon and husband of Hecuba; father of many children, including Hector, Paris, Cassandra, and Polyxena
theseus: King of Athens in the generation prior to the Trojan War. thessaly: A large region in northern Greece
tyndareus: King of Sparta, husband of Leda; the ‘‘mortal father’’ of Helen and other children said to have been sired by Zeus
